semantic_title: Coding Guidelines for Underdosing of Medications
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 19. Chapter 19: Injury, poisoning, and certain other consequences of external causes > e. Adverse Effects, Poisoning, Underdosing and Toxic Effects > (c) Underdosing

content.full_text: Underdosing refers to taking less of a medication than is prescribed by a provider or a manufacturer's instruction. Discontinuing the use of a prescribed medication on the patient's own initiative (not directed by the patient's provider) is also classified as an underdosing. For underdosing, assign the code from categories T36-T50 (fifth or sixth character "6"). Documentation of a change in the patient's condition is not required in order to assign an underdosing code. Documentation that the patient is taking less of a medication than is prescribed or discontinued the prescribed medication is sufficient for code assignment. Codes for underdosing should never be assigned as principal or first-listed codes. If a patient has a relapse or exacerbation of the medical condition for which the drug is prescribed because of the reduction in dose, then the medical condition itself should be coded. Noncompliance (Z91.12-, Z91.13-, Z91.14- and Z91.A4-) or complication of care (Y63.6-Y63.9) codes are to be used with an underdosing code to indicate intent, if known. (Evidence: pg no: 84-85, L8-L16)
content.summary: Underdosing includes taking less medication than prescribed or discontinuing medication without provider direction, coded with T36-T50 using character 6 (Evidence: pg no: 84-85, L8-L16)
key_concepts: T36-T50 character 6 coding (Evidence: pg no: 84, L11)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Underdosing refers to taking less of a medication than is prescribed by a provider or a manufacturer's instruction (Evidence: pg no: 84, L8-L10)
detailed_rules.explanation: Underdosing encompasses both taking reduced amounts of prescribed medication and completely discontinuing medication without provider direction (Evidence: pg no: 84, L8-L11)

detailed_rules.rule_text: For underdosing, assign the code from categories T36-T50 (fifth or sixth character "6") (Evidence: pg no: 84, L11)
detailed_rules.explanation: Underdosing codes use the specific character 6 in the fifth or sixth position of T36-T50 codes (Evidence: pg no: 84, L11)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Documentation of a change in the patient's condition is not required in order to assign an underdosing code (Evidence: pg no: 84, L12)
detailed_rules.explanation: Underdosing can be coded based solely on documentation of reduced medication intake, without requiring evidence of clinical consequences (Evidence: pg no: 84, L12-L13)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Codes for underdosing should never be assigned as principal or first-listed codes (Evidence: pg no: 84, L13-L14)
detailed_rules.explanation: Underdosing codes are always secondary codes and cannot be used as the primary reason for encounter (Evidence: pg no: 84, L13-L14)

detailed_rules.rule_text: If a patient has a relapse or exacerbation of the medical condition for which the drug is prescribed because of the reduction in dose, then the medical condition itself should be coded (Evidence: pg no: 84, L13-L15)
detailed_rules.explanation: When underdosing results in worsening of the underlying condition, code the medical condition as primary with underdosing as secondary (Evidence: pg no: 84, L13-L15)
common_applications: Seizure recurrence due to reduced anticonvulsant
Hypertensive crisis due to missed antihypertensive

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify if patient took less medication than prescribed or discontinued medication
Step 2: Assign appropriate T36-T50 code with character 6
Step 3: Determine primary condition (never use underdosing as primary)
Step 4: Add noncompliance or complication of care codes if intent known
Step 5: Code any resulting medical condition exacerbation as primary

code_ranges.description: Poisoning by, adverse effects of and underdosing of drugs, medicaments and biological substances (Evidence: pg no: 84, L11)
usage_rules: Never assign as principal or first-listed codes (Evidence: pg no: 84, L13-L14)
Use fifth or sixth character "6" (Evidence: pg no: 84, L11)

code_ranges.requirement: Use with underdosing codes to indicate intent
usage_rules: Use when intent is known (Evidence: pg no: 84-85, L16)

code_ranges.description: Complication of care codes (Evidence: pg no: 84-85, L16)
code_ranges.requirement: Use with underdosing codes to indicate intent
usage_rules: Use when intent is known (Evidence: pg no: 84-85, L16)

code_patterns.description: Underdosing codes use character 6 in fifth or sixth position (Evidence: pg no: 84, L11)

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient with diabetes stops taking insulin without provider direction, develops diabetic ketoacidosis
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient with Type 1 diabetes discontinued insulin injections 3 days ago without consulting physician, now presents with DKA
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify insulin discontinuation as underdosing
Step 2: Code DKA as primary condition
Step 3: Add underdosing code as secondary
Step 4: Add noncompliance code if appropriate

correct_coding.sequencing: Medical condition first, underdosing second, noncompliance third
correct_coding.rationale: Underdosing never principal, medical condition exacerbation coded first (Evidence: pg no: 84, L13-L15)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Cannot use underdosing as principal diagnosis
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Using underdosing code as primary diagnosis

warnings: Never assign underdosing codes as principal or first-listed codes (Evidence: pg no: 84, L13-L14)
best_practices: Document medication adherence issues clearly (Evidence: pg no: 84, L12-L13)
Always look for resulting medical condition exacerbations (Evidence: pg no: 84, L13-L15)
common_mistakes: Using underdosing codes as primary diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 84, L13-L14)
Not coding resulting medical condition exacerbations (Evidence: pg no: 84, L13-L15)
tips: Documentation of condition change not required for underdosing code assignment (Evidence: pg no: 84, L12)
Use noncompliance codes when intent is documented (Evidence: pg no: 84-85, L14-L16)
